image.altText: A group of women hug and smile in a crowd of people

props.synopsis: Both houses of the US Congress have agreed to force Justice officials to release documents relating to the investigation into convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein. Follow live.

title.children: Trump to now decide whether to release Epstein files

image.altText: Couple sits on bench looking out at sea.

props.synopsis: Superannuation products that fail the federal government's performance test are still offered to those already retired at a potentially huge cost, according to the consumer advocate.

title.children: How retirees are failed by Australia's superannuation system

image.altText: A hand holds a wallet with cash coming out.

props.synopsis: ABS figures show workers received a real pay increase over the past year, but economists warn that is likely to flip over coming months as inflation increases and wages growth slows further.

title.children: Wage growth remains steady, just ahead of inflation

image.altText: Jess Wilson wearing a white top and blue blazer standing in front of green hedges.

props.synopsis: The Liberals in two big Australian states are realigning themselves — shifting to what Sussan Ley once described as the sensible centre.

title.children: Liberals in two big states are realigning themselves to the centre

image.altText: A collage of the different plans

props.synopsis: As Donald Trump's plan for Gaza gets UN approval, the proposals for how the territory might be developed are circulating and advocates are worried about who they ultimately benefit.

title.children: How 'disaster capitalism' is looking to cash in on Gaza's misery

image.altText: US President Donald Trump shakes hands with the Saudi Crown Prince smiling.

props.synopsis: US President Donald Trump warmly welcomes the Saudi crown prince to the White House where he deflects journalists' questions about Mohammed bin Salman's role in the killing of reporter Jamal Khashoggi, saying: "Things happened, but he knew nothing about it."

title.children: 'Things happen': Trump defends Saudi prince over killing of Washington Post journalist

image.altText: CSIRO scientist in lab

props.synopsis: The chief executive of the CSIRO has defended the decision to cut hundreds of jobs, arguing the organisation needs to alter its priorities to remain relevant.

title.children: 'The cost of science has gone up': CSIRO chief defends job cuts

image.altText: The ASX building exterior.

props.synopsis: ABS figures show workers received an average base pay increase of 3.4 per cent over the year to September, in line with the previous quarter and economist forecasts. Webjet shares soar after a takeover offer from rival Helloworld. Follow live.

title.children: Webjet shares soar on takeover offer, wages growth up 3.4 per cent

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Takeover offer sends Webjet Group shares soaring
Gold miners shine as ASX tech stocks fall sharply

image.altText: The Bureau of Meteorology's cyclone tracking map

props.synopsis: A tropical low off the Northern Territory coast has intensified to become Tropical Cyclone Fina with potential landfall expected as early as Friday.

title.children: Tropical Cyclone Fina could make landfall in NT by Friday

image.altText: A woman and a man standing inside a newsroom and smiling at the camera, with television screens in the background.

props.synopsis: Some people refer to attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder as "a superpower" while others describe their ADHD symptoms as debilitating. Can both be true?

title.children: What the experts want you to know about these key ADHD symptoms

image.altText: Sussan Ley speak to the media.

props.synopsis: Sussan Ley has flagged she will release her plan for Australia's migration program by Christmas but she will not say just how much the Coalition wants the intake cut by. Follow live.

title.children: Coalition to propose cut to migration but will not name target

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: ABC's MD kicks off speech at the Press Club
State and territory leaders meet over hospital stoush
'She's clearly bitter': Nampijinpa Price hits back at former senator who quit Liberals

image.altText: Gloved hands use tweezers to examine pink coloured sand in a zip-lock bag.

props.synopsis: One Queensland grandmother says her daughter had vacuumed, and even replaced her vacuum cleaner, after removing the asbestos-contaminated sand following "confusing" advice.

title.children: Families left unsure how to clean homes after asbestos sand concerns

image.altText: A close-up of a phone with words on it

props.synopsis: Cloudflare says it has fully restored services after a "latent bug" sent major platforms including X and ChatGPT into a tailspin. Here's what we know.

title.children: What we know about the Cloudflare outage that impacted X and ChatGPT

image.altText: Mohamed Touré kicks the ball with his right foot for the Socceroos against Colombia.

props.synopsis: After falling to a meek 1-0 loss to Venezuela on Saturday, the Socceroos will be looking for an improved performance against Colombia in New York. Follow live.

title.children: Socceroos continue World Cup preparation with friendly against Colombia

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Socceroos starting XI: Irvine, McGree return from the start
What time does today's match begin?

image.altText: Scott McTominay executes a bicycle kick to score a goal for Scotland against Denmark.

props.synopsis: A breathtaking goal from Scott McTominay paves the way for Scotland to qualify for the World Cup finals after a 28-year absence.

title.children: Scotland ends 28-year World Cup absence after breathtaking bicycle kick goal

image.altText: A man and woman sitting at a dining table looking intensely at paperwork and a calculator

props.synopsis: Switching to fortnightly repayments from monthly — if you can afford it — can help you pay down your mortgage faster. Here’s why.

title.children: Should you make mortgage repayments monthly, fortnightly or weekly?

image.altText: A man with short dark grey hair, in a suit and tie, smiling with his nose scrunched up, with a trophy in the background

props.synopsis: The prestigious Booker Prize, worth $100,000, announced its 2025 winner last week. Do you remember who won? Test your knowledge of the world's favourite book awards with our quiz.

title.children: Quiz: Do you remember who won the Booker just a week ago?

image.altText: A boy in a black jumper with a red sash.

props.synopsis: The brother of schoolboy Terry Floyd, who disappeared 50 years ago, has accused the Victorian government of breaking its public promise to fund the search for his remains.

title.children: Victorian government breaks promise to murdered child's family

image.altText: A nuclear power plant stack surrounded by razor wire and an American flag in the background

props.synopsis: Once the site of the worst commercial nuclear power accident in the US, Pennsylvania's Three Mile Island will again start producing electricity after the Department of Energy agreed to a $US1 billion ($1.5 billion) loan.

title.children: From meltdown to restart, US nuclear power plant gets a second life

image.altText: An army tank

props.synopsis: Information relating to Australian military programs has been compromised in cyber attacks on defence industry contractors, exposing security vulnerabilities along supply chains.

title.children: ADF weapons programs exposed in defence industry cyber attacks

image.altText: A man in a crown and fur coat sits on a regal throne looking neutrally at something out of frame

props.synopsis: Tongans are heading to the polls this week amid concerns that democratic reforms in the country could be short-lived.

title.children: After 15 years of democracy, is Tonga turning back to its king?

image.altText: Sunshine Coast path

props.synopsis: The boy has been charged with dangerous operation of a vehicle causing death, unlicensed driving, and driving an unregistered and uninsured vehicle.

title.children: Boy, 15, charged over fatal Sunshine Coast e-bike crash that killed 8yo child

image.altText: A woman's hands holding a Nintendo Wii Remote controller

props.synopsis: Innovative motion controls and accessible design made the Nintendo Wii one of the most popular consoles of all time.

title.children: Nintendo gave away millions of games for free. The risk paid off

image.altText: A close up of a pile of sugar beets. They look like large, pale root vegetables  covered in dirt

props.synopsis: Sugar beet has not been grown in Australia for almost a century, but as the need for sustainable aviation fuels intensifies, the traditionally European crop could be making a paddock comeback.

title.children: New crop could be Australia's sustainable aviation fuel sweet spot

image.altText: Three elderly men standing in front of a shed entrance with a serious look on their face

props.synopsis: The future of the Gympie Men's Shed is in doubt as the search for a new home continues.

title.children: Queensland men's shed still without a home after being evicted

image.altText: Two men wearing high-vis orange shirts and yellow hard hats wrap a power pole in mesh

props.synopsis: A fire-resistant mesh is being used to protect thousands of wooden power poles from bushfires across the NSW Central Coast and Hunter regions.

title.children: Power poles wrapped in protective mesh ahead of bushfire season

image.altText: A graphic showing a Samsung phone and the logos of telecommunications companies.

props.synopsis: There are growing questions about whether one of Australia's largest telcos could have done more to ensure customers would be able to call Triple Zero.

title.children: Samsung phones 'slipped through the cracks' before Triple Zero tragedy

image.altText: A man and young boy (right) hold coloured cards, the boy holds a green one to the camera and looks at the lens.

props.synopsis: With only eight fluent Nyiyaparli speakers remaining, an Aboriginal group is racing against time to save their 41,000-year-old language.

title.children: Game designed to save dying Aboriginal language wins global awards

image.altText: People crown around ambulances outside a hospital in Lebanon.

props.synopsis: It was the deadliest strike on Lebanon since a ceasefire in the Israel-Hezbollah war a year ago.

title.children: Israeli air strike on a Palestinian refugee camp in Lebanon kills 13

image.altText: a groupd of about sixty people from the National Socialist Network dressed in black at a rally outside parliament house sydney

props.synopsis: Police and courts will be given greater powers to combat public displays of Nazi ideology in NSW following a rally outside state parliament earlier this month.

title.children: New laws to combat neo-Nazis in NSW after parliament rally

image.altText: Image of a bearded man wearing a hooded jumper.

props.synopsis: A Gippsland sawmill owned by Australia's largest softwood producer is set to shut immediately, with more than 70 jobs lost.

title.children: Timber workers lose jobs at Victorian sawmill weeks before Christmas

image.altText: Sullivan Robey celebrates a goal playing for Eastern Ranges

props.synopsis: Another AFL draft has arrived, offering dozens of teenage footballers the chance to realise their dreams. Here is everything you need to know.

title.children: How to watch the AFL draft and everything else you need to know

image.altText: Stephanie Gilmore smiles and turns to her right during a media event at Bells Beach in 2025.

props.synopsis: Two years after stepping away from the tour, Australian surfing legend Stephanie Gilmore will make her return in 2026 after being awarded a season wildcard.

title.children: Eight-time world champion Gilmore announces surfing comeback
